awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: GOALI: Evaluating thermo-electro-adsorption mechanisms for waste-heat driven ion-separation processes
awd_abstract_narration:
In the case of a natural disaster, drinking water quality may be significantly compromised. Remote areas may not have access to centralized water treatment.  A low cost, modular water treatment device that operates using only electricity powered by renewable energy would address these concerns. Many current modular water treatment devices require elevated temperatures and pressures, which are not well suited for remote applications. In contrast, capacitive deionization is an electrochemical technique to desalinate water that uses only electricity and operates at ambient conditions. This project seeks to advance the energy efficiency of capacitive deionization to enable easily deployable water treatment.  

The premise of this work is to measure and evaluate through theory and experiments how  thermal energy generated within a capacitive deionization cell and applied external to the cell (through waste heat) affect electric double layer salt removal dynamics. We intend to probe local electric double layer properties through performing in situ analytical measurements (calorimetry, coulometry, microscopy, scattering). Complimentary bulk (system level) experiments will be used to evaluate the energetics associated with electric double layer based separations in dilute aqueous systems (brackish water treatment). Ultimately, the aim is to better understand how waste heat can be best utilized, to aid ion packing and maximize desalination performance. This is fundamental to many fields of electrochemistry, colloid science and an emerging issue in water treatment. This approach will also provide a new benchmark for studying these electrochemical separation technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Separations applications are widely present in a range of industries including and not limited to water desalination, chemical separations, environmental remediation, and CO2 capture. The most common examples of existing separation technologies include adsorption, absorption, and membrane-based technologies. Adsorption approaches separate constituents via binding interactions that occur at the surface of the adsorbent (e.g. separation material). This separation mechanism is dependent on the accessible surface area of the material. There has been a wide range of engineering and scientific research focused on developing novel materials with very high surface areas and tailoring the surface properties to allow for high removal rates and higher selectivity. A branch of adsorption separations is known as electroadsorption. Electroadsorption refers to adsorbents that are exposed to an electrical bias. Applying an electric field or bias can change the electroadsorbent charge and affect the separations process.  Specifically, field-driven separation mechanisms can influence the separation capacity, separation rate, and separation selectivity. There is significant interest in electroadsorption materials because they may be able to be tailored to provide precise separations related to selective ion removal from sea water in application related to lithium mining and may be a viable separations approach for complex separations that manifest if dilute concentrations. Moreover, field driven separations approaches may be able to be powered by renewable electricity and thus represents a pathway toward decarbonizing energy intensive separations process. In this proposal, we examined novel mechanism for separation that are guided by dual gradients: thermal and electric field.

 

The broader impacts of this award seeks to develop pathways for new low energy intensive separations technologies. Currently, membrane separations technologies are favorable in most separation applications. In applications like desalination, membranes are approaching the thermodynamic minimum energy required to achieve separations. However, in dilute applications such as brackish water systems, membrane systems are often not effective. This proposal examines pathways to specifically look at decreasing energy requirements associated with dilute separations. A second aim of this proposal aims to look at selectivity. Selectivity, describe the ability to precisely tailor an interface or material to remove a constituent or ion of interest. Selective separations have wide applications in lithium recovery and rare earth metal recovery applications. Aside from the technological application of this work, this grant directly supported the training of one phd graduate student in mechanical engineering.

 

The intellectual merit of this award has focused on understanding the fundamental science that affects selective separations at novel adsorbent and electroadsorbent interfaces. In this work we examined 3-D porous materials and 2-D layered materials to understand the role geometric structural properties across various length scales influence selectivity. To unravel the impact chemistry and structure influenced selective transport this proposal employed a range of advanced characterization and diagnostic tools ranging from electrochemical dilatometry to ambient pressure synchrotron x-ray spectroscopy. Studies that examine the basic science of separation can aid in the development of next generation separation materials capable of energy efficient separations.

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2022
Modified by: Kelsey B Hatzell

Image
  • In situ electrochemical atomic force microscopy was utilized to monitor mechanical changes upon electroadsorption and desorption (a). Force distance curves can be used to identify physical properties such as adhesion, stiffness, and compliance.(b) Deformation as a function of charge rate.
    K.B. Hatzell and M.C. Hatzell
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Kelsey B Hatzell
    In situ Dilatometry
